overview_of_class: This graduate seminar examines the intersection of language and law, taking legal institutions as important sites for the creation, negotiation, and reformulation of social and cultural norms and practices. We will consider the ways in which culture and language shape law, and the ways in which law conditions and constrains culture and language. The legal anthropological texts we read pay close attention to spoken and written language. The linguistic anthropological readings take the courtroom and disputes as their objects of analysis. We will consider in cross-cultural perspective such matters as testimony, evidence, persuasion, performance, linguistic rights as human rights, and gender. Throughout, questions of power, agency, and inequality (especially around gender and race/ethnicity) animate our investigations. Course materials include ethnographies, theoretical works, and primary sources.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
* Conley (2016), Confronting the Death Penalty. Oxford.
* Srimati Basu (2015) The Trouble with Marriage: Feminists Confront Law and Violence in India. U CA Press.
* Conley, John M., and William M. O'Barr (2005) Just Words: Law, Language, and Power. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
* Hirsch, Susan (1998) Pronouncing and Persevering: Gender and the Discourses of Disputing in an African Islamic Court. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
* Merry, Sally Engle (2006) Human Rights and Gender Violence: Translating International Law into Local Justice. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
+ Course packet of articles and chapters (also posted on Canvas)

May be revised

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Anth 484 is a yearly seminar in linguistic anthropology with rotating themes (media, law, language ideologies, semiotics, etc.). It may be taken multiple times for credit.
